notes.content: Start prep from the official FPSC outline and recent descriptive papers to lock scope, weightage, and command words.
keyTakeaways: Use FPSC syllabus PDF to map topics into weekly plan.
Study recent descriptive papers to see examiner phrasing and favored areas.
Cross-check private websites with FPSC originals.

notes.title: Prosody (Ilm-e-Arooz): Behr, Wazn, Taqti, Qafiya, Radeef
notes.content: Prosody underpins poetry analysis. Examiners often test forms, meters, and scansion with examples from ghazal/nazm.
keyTakeaways: Memorize major behren and common arkaan; practice taqti on famous couplets.
Know difference between ghazal structure vs. nazm cohesion.
Use tools + canonical texts to validate scansion.

notes.title: Major Forms of Urdu Poetry: Ghazal, Nazm, Masnavi, Marsiya, Qasida
notes.content: CSS frequently asks definitions, structure, evolution, and exemplars of major forms, plus comparative analysis (e.g., ghazal vs. nazm).
keyTakeaways: Ghazal = autonomous shers + radeef/qafiya; Nazm = thematic unity.
Masnavi for narrative; Marsiya for elegy; Qasida for panegyric.
Quote 2–3 canonical poets per form.

resources.title: RekhtaLearning — Major Forms of Urdu Poetry (blog)

notes.title: Hali's 'Muqaddama-e-Sher-o-Shairi' — The First Critical Manifesto
notes.content: Foundational Urdu poetics/criticism; compare with Wordsworth's Lyrical Ballads preface. Establishes realism, morality, language reform.
keyTakeaways: Cite Hali's criteria for 'useful' literature and style.
Use for questions on criticism, reform, and classic-to-modern transition.
Pair with Azad's 'Aab-e-Hayat' for canon formation debates.

notes.title: Azad's 'Aab-e-Hayat' — Shaping the Canon
notes.content: Seminal history that codified Urdu poetic tradition; useful for historiography and canon debates (biases, selections, periodization).
keyTakeaways: Understand Azad's narrative of Urdu's evolution.
Cross-reference with modern histories (e.g., Jalibi) for critique.
Quote where Azad positions classical poets.

notes.title: Mirza Ghalib — Classical Peak of the Ghazal
notes.content: For poet-specific essays, focus on linguistic play, philosophical irony, and letters' role in modern Urdu prose.
keyTakeaways: Anchor answers with 2–3 couplets (with accurate scansion).
Use letters to evidence modern sensibility.
Contrast with Mir/Daagh; connect to Delhi 1857 milieu.

notes.title: Allama Muhammad Iqbal — Philosophical Modernism in Urdu
notes.content: Iqbal's nazm/masnavi fuse metaphysics (khudi), activism, and Muslim modernity; frequently examined within ideology & style.
keyTakeaways: Explain khudi with textual evidence.
Relate poetic form to message (didactic but lyrical).
Cite reputable lectures/academy material.

notes.title: Faiz Ahmed Faiz — Love, Revolution, and the Progressive Voice
notes.content: Faiz synthesizes ishq & inqilab; contextualize within PWM (Taraqqi Pasand Tehreek) and post-Partition politics.
keyTakeaways: Quote early romantic vs. later resistance poetry.
Link Lenin Peace Prize and exile periods to themes.
Discuss craft: imagery, metaphor, ghazal innovations.

notes.title: Saadat Hasan Manto — Modern Urdu Afsana (Short Story)
notes.content: For prose critique/analysis, Manto's realism on partition, sexuality, and hypocrisy is central; expect text-based questions.
keyTakeaways: Prepare summaries + critical angles for Toba Tek Singh, Khol Do, Thanda Gosht.
Understand PWM tensions with Manto's stance.
Use specific narrative techniques (irony, economy, dialogue).

resources.title: Wikipedia — Saadat Hasan Manto (updated works list)

notes.title: Premchand — Social Realism across Urdu/Hindi
notes.content: Premchand bridges Urdu/Hindi; questions often compare themes, characterization, and reformist impulse (Sevasadan, Godaan).
keyTakeaways: Discuss language/register choice and publication history.
Tie stories/novels to colonial modernity & ethics.
Quote 1–2 emblematic scenes.

notes.title: Progressive Writers' Movement (Taraqqi Pasand Tehreek)
notes.content: Core modern movement influencing poetry, afsana, and criticism; frequently tested for origins, ideology, and key figures.
keyTakeaways: Origins in Angarey (1932); London manifesto; Sajjad Zaheer, M.D. Taseer, Ahmed Ali, Mulk Raj Anand.
Themes: anti-imperialism, social justice; debates over 'propagandist' vs. 'progressive' art.
Link to Faiz, Krishan Chander, Ismat, Manto (contested).

notes.title: Modern Trends & Scholarship on Contemporary Urdu
notes.content: Use current research to enrich answers on modern Urdu's themes, forms, and readership.
keyTakeaways: Cite recent peer-reviewed studies where relevant.
Tie digital/linguistic shifts to literary consumption.
Balance tradition vs. innovation arguments.

resources.title: The progressiveness of Urdu literature through poetry

notes.title: Urdu's Digital Future & Script Issues (Context point)
notes.content: Background insight for essays on language, readership, and media: Nastaliq digitization, OCR, keyboards, and learning.
keyTakeaways: Script tech affects accessibility and study of classics.
Rekhta's digitization & tools are pivotal.
Use as contemporary context, not core literary answer.

resources.title: TIME — Preserving Urdu Script in Digital World

notes.title: Dictionaries & Language Tools for Close Reading
notes.content: Accurate meanings drive better explication; use multiple dictionaries for classical vs. modern usage.
keyTakeaways: Rekhta (trilingual) for poetry vocabulary in context.
Platts for classical/etymology; UT Austin usage guide.
Lexilogos hub for multiple references.

resources.title: UT Austin — Using an Urdu Dictionary

notes.title: Urdu Literature in the Independence Movement
notes.content: Contextual essay angle: literature as nation-making, political consciousness, and resistance.
keyTakeaways: Afsana & nazm as mobilizing genres.
Cite Iqbal, Akbar, Shibli; journals like Adab-e-Latif.
Link PWM to pre-Partition activism.

notes.title: Jameel Jalibi — 'Tareekh-e-Adab-e-Urdu' (Modern Historiography)
notes.content: Use Jalibi's multi-volume history to balance Azad/Hali; cite when discussing periods, trends, and textual evidence.
keyTakeaways: Acknowledge method & limits; triangulate with other histories.
Quote volume-wise insights when relevant.
Good for 'history of Urdu literature' essay prompts.

resources.title: Critical overview of Jalibi's history (research article)

notes.title: Past Papers (2000→recent) — Trend Analysis & Practice
notes.content: Practice writing time-bound, text-anchored answers using past questions; update themes (forms, PWM, author essays).
keyTakeaways: Attempt at least 10 past essay questions with citations.
Collect repeated topics (Progressives, Iqbal, forms, prosody).
Mark command words: discuss, evaluate, compare, illustrate.

notes.title: MCQs & Objective Prep (Terminology, Authors, Forms)
notes.content: Objective section tests terms (behr, radeef), dates, journals, movements, and author–work mapping.
keyTakeaways: Build a personal MCQ bank from past papers.
Prioritize forms/terminology and author biographies.
Verify answers against reliable sources.

resources.title: CSS Exam — Past Paper MCQs hub

notes.title: Rekhta — Primary Library for Texts, Poets, and Tools
notes.content: Use Rekhta as your default library for authentic texts, poet pages, ebooks, and learning content.
keyTakeaways: Always cross-verify couplets' variants and references.
Use author pages to discover related works.
Leverage learning/blog for exam-ready summaries.

notes.title: Video Masterclasses & Lecture Playlists
notes.content: Use curated lectures to strengthen conceptual clarity and quoteable insights.
keyTakeaways: Note 1–2 memorable lines per lecture for essays.
Prefer institutional channels for reliability.
Use prosody playlists to reinforce scansion.

notes.title: Form-Focused Answering: Ghazal vs. Nazm
notes.content: Exam often asks comparisons; prepare crisp, example-rich distinctions with scansion and structure points.
keyTakeaways: Ghazal: matla/makhta, radeef/qafiya; couplet autonomy.
Nazm: unity of theme; free vs. rhymed forms.
Add 2–3 poet examples per form.

notes.title: Author-Work Mapping Sheets (Ghalib, Iqbal, Faiz, Manto, Premchand)
notes.content: Prepare a table mapping authors to key works, dates, styles, and 1–2 quotable lines for rapid recall.
keyTakeaways: Memorize 3–5 canonical works per author.
Keep 1–2 critical opinions (with source) per figure.
Use for MCQs and essay intros.

notes.title: Language Learning Aids (for non-native candidates)
notes.content: If needed, strengthen script and pronunciation to avoid mis-quoting or mis-scanning poetry in the exam.
keyTakeaways: Polish Nastaliq reading & talaffuz.
Use structured modules for script/vocab.
Combine with dictionary drills.

notes.title: Contextual Reading: Classical → Modern Continuum
notes.content: Connect classical heritage (Mir, Ghalib) to modern/progressive phases; show continuity and rupture in themes and forms.
keyTakeaways: Use Azad/Hali to explain canon shifts.
Position PWM within 1930s–50s socio-politics.
Cite modern scholarship to update arguments.
